Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the video shows Trump attending an interfaith prayer service at a church in Washington, DC, after his inauguration as US president in 2017. The claim falsely states that it shows a Koran recitation in a US Senate meeting.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the event by stating that it is the first time in history that the US President and Senate opened a meeting with the Koran.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or credible sources to back up the assertion that the White House asked for an imam/Islamic scholar to pray in order to be kept away from the corona outbreak.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the presence of a Koran recitation at an interfaith prayer service indicates that the White House acknowledges Islam as a true religion and seeks guidance to Islam.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider the alternative explanation that the video shows Trump and Pence attending a National Prayer Service at the Washington National Cathedral, which is an inaugural tradition.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting misleading information and misinterpretation of the video, leading to a false conclusion about a Koran recitation in a US Senate meeting.
Understate: There is no evidence of any understatement bias in the provided claim.
